page.title: 02Landscape of Charnwood
page.content: In the interior of Charnwood Forest and famous for its geology,natural beauty and fine views this area is 600 to 800ft above sea level and forms the watershed between the tributaries of the R.Soar.It is a volcanic landscape of pre Cambrian rocks rising craggily out of smooth marly valleys.The highest point is Beacon Hill 248m once an Iron Age hill fort the banks and ditches of its fortifications still visible under the bracken and the lower slopes covered by birches and rhodedendrons.Further W Copt Oak at 236m is another commanding point. Between these the Ulverscroft valley runs southward where the ruins of Ulverscroft Priory lie hidden close to the only large pool in the area.The thin stony soils are cultivated almost to the hilltops with considerable grass land on the upper slopes.
